form.longName: PhenX PX710101 - Quality Of Communication About Smoking
form.preferredDefinition: This is a series of six self-administered questions that ask an adolescent about communication with his or her mother about smoking. The response options are a Likert scale.

question.questionText: My mother and I are interested in each other's opinions on smoking (mother_interested_opinions_smoking)
My mother and I are able to talk easily about our opinions concerning smoking (mother_talk_opinions_smoking)
When my mother and I are talking about smoking we both feel comfortable (mother_talk_smoking_comfortable)
When talking about smoking I think my mother is dishonest and unreasonable (mother_talk_smoking_dishonest)
Whenever my mother and I discuss smoking, I feel she understands me (mother_discuss_smoking_understanding)
Whenever my mother and I discuss smoking I feel she takes me seriously (mother_discuss_smoking_serious)

protocol.preferredDefinition: This is a series of six self-administered questions that ask an adolescent about communication with his or her mother about smoking. The response options are a Likert scale.

form.longName: PhenX PX710201 - Frequency Of Communication About Smoking
form.preferredDefinition: This is a series of eight self-administered questions that ask an adolescent about communication with his or her mother about smoking. The response options are a Likert scale.

question.questionText: During the last 12 months, how many times did your mother encourage you to refrain from smoking? (frequency_mother_encourage_refranin_smoking)
During the last 12 months, how many times did your mother discourage you to have friends who smoke? (frequency_mother_discorage_friends_smoking)
During the last 12 months, how many times did your mother discuss the dangers of smoking with you? (frequency_mother_discuss_dangers_smoking)
During the last 12 months, how many times did your mother talk with you about what you can and cannot do with regard to smoking? (frequency_mother_talk_cannnot_smoking)
During the last 12 months, how many times did your mother talk about punishment if you smoked? (frequency_mother_punishment_smoking)
During the last 12 months, how many times did your mother tell you not to smoke? (frequency_mother_tell_not_smoking)
During the last 12 months, how many times did your mother talk with you about the glamorizing of film and screen smoking? (frequency_mother_talk_glamorizing_smoking)
During the last 12 months, how many times did your mother advise you how to resist peer pressure to use tobacco? (frequency_mother_advise_resist_pressure_smoking)

protocol.preferredDefinition: This is a series of eight self-administered questions that ask an adolescent about communication with his or her mother about smoking. The response options are a Likert scale.

form.longName: PhenX PX710401 - Behavior Economics Purchase Behavior
form.preferredDefinition: The Cigarette Purchase Task (CPT) is a simulation procedure to assess reinforcement efficacy of cigarettes within a specific context. The CPT came from an adaptation of a progressive-ratio operant schedule and early studies were a bit literal in the use of doubling response requirements, up to prices that were not plausible in the current market. Subsequent studies have involved using different prices to find the right balance of precision and comprehensiveness.

headerInstruction.text: CPT State assessment: Imagine that you could smoke RIGHT NOW. The following questions ask how many cigarettes you would consume if they cost various amounts of money. Assume the available cigarettes are your favorite brand. Assume that you ha..TRUNCATED

question.questionText: How many cigarettes would you smoke RIGHT NOW if they were FREE? [$0/pack] (right_now_cig_smoke_0)
How many cigarettes would you smoke RIGHT NOW if they were 1¢ each? [20¢/pack] (right_now_cig_smoke_1cent)
How many cigarettes would you smoke RIGHT NOW if they were 5¢ each? [$1/pack] (right_now_cig_smoke_5cents)
How many cigarettes would you smoke RIGHT NOW if they were 13¢ each? [$2.60/pack] (right_now_cig_smoke_13cents)
How many cigarettes would you smoke RIGHT NOW if they were 25¢ each? [$5.00/pack] (right_now_cig_smoke_25cents)
How many cigarettes would you smoke RIGHT NOW if they were 50¢ each? [$10/pack] (right_now_cig_smoke_50cents)
How many cigarettes would you smoke RIGHT NOW if they were $1 each? [$20/pack] (right_now_cig_smoke_1dollar)
How many cigarettes would you smoke RIGHT NOW if they were $2 each? [$40/pack] (right_now_cig_smoke_2dollar)
How many cigarettes would you smoke RIGHT NOW if they were $3 each? [$60/pack] (right_now_cig_smoke_3dollar)
How many cigarettes would you smoke RIGHT NOW if they were $4 each? [$80/pack] (right_now_cig_smoke_4dollar)
How many cigarettes would you smoke RIGHT NOW if they were $5 each? [$100/pack] (right_now_cig_smoke_5dollar)
How many cigarettes would you smoke RIGHT NOW if they were $6 each? [$120/pack] (right_now_cig_smoke_6dollar)
How many cigarettes would you smoke RIGHT NOW if they were $11 each? [$220/pack] (right_now_cig_smoke_11dollar)
How many cigarettes would you smoke RIGHT NOW if they were $35 each? [$700 pack] (right_now_cig_smoke_35dollar)
How many cigarettes would you smoke RIGHT NOW if they were $70 each? [$1,400/pack] (right_now_cig_smoke_70dollar)
How many cigarettes would you smoke RIGHT NOW if they were $140 each? [$2,800/pack] (right_now_cig_smoke_140dollar)
How many cigarettes would you smoke RIGHT NOW if they were $280 each? [$5,600/pack] (right_now_cig_smoke_280dollar)
How many cigarettes would you smoke RIGHT NOW if they were $560 each? [$11,200/pack] (right_now_cig_smoke_560dollar)
How many cigarettes would you smoke RIGHT NOW if they were $1,120 each? [$22,400/pack] (right_now_cig_smoke_1120dollar)
How many cigarettes would you smoke on a typical day if they were FREE? [$0/pack] (typical_day_cig_smoke_0)
How many cigarettes would you smoke on a typical day if they were 1¢ each? [20¢/pack] (typical_day_cig_smoke_1cent)
How many cigarettes would you smoke on a typical day if they were 5¢ each? [$1/pack] (typical_day_cig_smoke_5cents)
How many cigarettes would you smoke on a typical day if they were 13¢ each? [$2.60/pack] (typical_day_cig_smoke_13cents)
How many cigarettes would you smoke on a typical day if they were 25¢ each? [$5.00/pack] (typical_day_cig_smoke_25cents)
How many cigarettes would you smoke on a typical day if they were 50¢ each? [$10/pack] (typical_day_cig_smoke_50cents)
How many cigarettes would you smoke on a typical day if they were $1 each? [$20/pack] (typical_day_cig_smoke_1dollar)
How many cigarettes would you smoke on a typical day if they were $2 each? [$40/pack] (typical_day_cig_smoke_2dollar)
How many cigarettes would you smoke on a typical day if they were $3 each? [$60/pack] (typical_day_cig_smoke_3dollar)
How many cigarettes would you smoke on a typical day if they were $4 each? [$80/pack] (typical_day_cig_smoke_4dollar)
How many cigarettes would you smoke on a typical day if they were $5 each? [$100/pack] (typical_day_cig_smoke_5dollar)
How many cigarettes would you smoke on a typical day if they were $6 each? [$120/pack] (typical_day_6dollar)
How many cigarettes would you smoke on a typical day if they were $11 each? [$220/pack] (typical_day_11dollar)
How many cigarettes would you smoke on a typical day if they were $35 each? [$700/pack] (typical_day_cig_smoke_35dollar)
How many cigarettes would you smoke on a typical day if they were $70 each? [$1,400/pack] (typical_day_cig_smoke_70dollar)
How many cigarettes would you smoke on a typical day if they were $140 each? [$2,800/pack] (typical_day_cig_smoke_140dollar)
How many cigarettes would you smoke on a typical day if they were $280 each? [$5,600/pack] (typical_day_cig_smoke_280dollar)
How many cigarettes would you smoke on a typical day if they were $560 each? [$11,200/pack] (typical_day_cig_smoke_560dollar)

protocol.preferredDefinition: The Cigarette Purchase Task (CPT) is a simulation procedure to assess reinforcement efficacy of cigarettes within a specific context. The CPT came from an adaptation of a progressive-ratio operant schedule and early studies were a bit literal in the use of doubling response requirements, up to prices that were not plausible in the current market. Subsequent studies have involved using different prices to find the right balance of precision and comprehensiveness.

form.longName: PhenX PX710501 - Motivation To Quit Single Item
form.preferredDefinition: This protocol is a single item measuring motivation to quit smoking among those who want to quit smoking.

question.questionText: How motivated are you to quit smoking on a scale where 1 = not at all motivated" and 10 = "extremely motivated."" (motivation_quit_smoking)

protocol.preferredDefinition: This protocol is a single item measuring motivation to quit smoking among those who want to quit smoking.

form.longName: PhenX PX710502 - Motivation To Quit Multiple Item
form.preferredDefinition: The Reasons for Quitting (RFQ) Questionnaire is a 20-item protocol developed to assess specific motivations for smoking cessation. The RFQ is based on an intrinsic-extrinsic model of motivation for smoking cessation with 10 intrinsic items (health concerns, self-control) and 10 extrinsic items (immediate reinforcement, social pressure).

headerInstruction.text: SelfAdministered: What are your reasons for wanting to quit smoking at this time? Below is a list of reasons that smokers may have for quitting. Read each reason and decide how much it applies to you right now. Then choose ONE answer for each..TRUNCATED

question.questionText: Telephone Administered. Past smokers: This section is about reasons for quitting smoking. I am going to read you a list of twenty reasons that smokers may have for quitting. Please listen to each one and decide how true it was for you at the time you decided to quit. Then tell me if it was not at all true, a little true, moderately true, quite true, or extremely true when you decided to quit smoking. Current smokers who desire to quit: This section is about reasons for quitting smoking. I am going to read you a list of twenty reasons that smokers may have for quitting. Listen to each one and decide whether it is not at all true, a little true, moderately true, quite true, or extremely true for you right now. Current smokers who do not wish to quit: This section is about reasons for quitting smoking. Even though you don't want to quit smoking now, we are interested in finding out the various reasons why people may decide to quit. I'm going to read you a list of twenty reasons that smokers may have for quitting. Listen to each one and decide whether it would be: not at all true, a little true, quite true, or extremely true for you if you were to decide to quit. (telephone_admin_710502)
1. I WANT TO QUIT SMOKING: Because I am concerned that I will suffer from a serious illness if I don't quit smoking (quit_smoking_concerend_illness)
2. I WANT TO QUIT SMOKING: To show myself that I can quit smoking if I really want to (quit_smoking_show_myself)
3. I WANT TO QUIT SMOKING: So that my hair and clothes won't smell (quit_smoking_wont_smell)
4. I WANT TO QUIT SMOKING: Because my spouse, children, or other person I am close to will stop nagging me if I quit (quit_smoking_family_nagging)
5. I WANT TO QUIT SMOKING: Because I have noticed physical symptoms that smoking is hurting my health (quit_smoking_physical_symptoms)
6. I WANT TO QUIT SMOKING: Because I will like myself better if I quit smoking (quit_smoking_like_myself_better)
7. I WANT TO QUIT SMOKING: So that I will save money on smokingrelated costs such as dry cleaning (quit_smoking_save_money)
8. I WANT TO QUIT SMOKING: Because someone has given me an ultimatum (made a threat) to quit (quit_smoking_ultimatum)
9. I WANT TO QUIT SMOKING: Because I can graphically picture the effects that smoking has on my body (quit_smoking_effect_body)
10. I WANT TO QUIT SMOKING: So that I can feel in control of my life (quit_smoking_feel_control)
11. I WANT TO QUIT SMOKING: Because I won't burn holes in clothing or furniture (quit_smoking_wont_burn_holes)
12. I WANT TO QUIT SMOKING: Because I will receive a special gift if I quit (quit_smoking_receive_gift)
13. I WANT TO QUIT SMOKING: Because I have known other people who have died from serious illnesses that were caused by smoking (quit_smoking_know_died)
14. I WANT TO QUIT SMOKING: Because quitting smoking will prove that I can accomplish other things that are important to me (quit_smoking_prove_accomplishment)
15. I WANT TO QUIT SMOKING: Because I want to save money that I spend on cigarettes (quit_smoking_save_money_cigarettes)
16. I WANT TO QUIT SMOKING: Because people I am close to will be upset with me if I don't quit (quit_smoking_people_close_upset)
17. I WANT TO QUIT SMOKING: Because I am concerned that smoking will shorten my life (quit_smoking_concerned_shorten_life)
18. I WANT TO QUIT SMOKING: To prove to myself that I am not addicted to cigarettes (quit_smoking_prove_not_addicted)
19. I WANT TO QUIT SMOKING: So that I won't have to clean my house or car as often (quit_smoking_not_clean)
20. I WANT TO QUIT SMOKING: Because I will receive a financial reward for quitting (money from a friend or family member, bonus from work, etc.) (quit_smoking_financial_reward)

SCORING: Dimension ItemsIntrinsic, Health Concerns 1, 5, 9, 13, 17Intrinsic, SelfControl 2, 6, 10, 14, 18Extrinsic, Immediate Reinforcement 3, 7, 11, 15, 19Extrinsic, Social Pressure 4, 8, 12, 16, 20COMPUTATION: We score the scaled as average ratings across the relevant subdimension items. Items with missing ratings can be excluded from the denominator. For example, the health concerns score = Sum of items (1 + 5 + 9 + 13 + 17)/5If item #9 is missing data, the calculation would be the sum of items (1 + 5 + 13 + 17)/4Level of intrinsic relative to extrinsic motivation is calculated as a difference score with the extrinsic scale score subtracted from the intrinsic score. (scoring_710502)

protocol.preferredDefinition: The Reasons for Quitting (RFQ) Questionnaire is a 20-item protocol developed to assess specific motivations for smoking cessation. The RFQ is based on an intrinsic-extrinsic model of motivation for smoking cessation with 10 intrinsic items (health concerns, self-control) and 10 extrinsic items (immediate reinforcement, social pressure).

form.longName: PhenX PX710601 - Hedonic Tone Or Response To Pleasurable Situations
form.preferredDefinition: The Snaith-Hamilton Pleasure Scale (SHAPS) is a self-administered, paper-and-pencil questionnaire with 14 items assessing four domains of pleasure response/hedonic experience: interest/pastimes, social interaction, sensory experience, and food/drink.

headerInstruction.text: This questionnaire is designed to measure your ability to experience pleasure in the last few days. It is important to read each statement very carefully. Choose one of the boxes to indicate how much you agree or disagree with each statement.

module.longName: Hedonic Tone or Response to Pleasurable Situations
module.preferredDefinition: Hedonic Tone or Response to Pleasurable Situations

question.questionText: I would enjoy my favourite television or radio programme: (pleasure_television_radio)
I would enjoy being with my family or close friends: (pleasure_family_friends)
I would find pleasure in my hobbies and pastimes: (pleasure_hobbies_pastimes)
I would be able to enjoy my favourite meal: (pleasure_enjoy_favourite_meal)
I would enjoy a warm bath or refreshing shower: (pleasure_bath_shower)
I would find pleasure in the scent of flowers or the smell of a fresh sea breeze or freshly baked bread: (pleasure_scent)
I would enjoy seeing other people's smiling faces: (pleasure_smiling_faces)
I would enjoy looking smart when I have made an effort with my appearance: (pleasure_looking_smart_appearance)
I would enjoy reading a book, magazine or newspaper: (pleasure_reading)
I would enjoy a cup of tea or coffee or my favourite drink: (pleasure_tea_coffee_drink)
I would find pleasure in small things, e.g., bright sunny day, a telephone call from a friend: (pleasure_small_things)
I would be able to enjoy a beautiful landscape or view: (pleasure_landscape_view)
I would get pleasure from helping others: (pleasure_helping_others)
I would feel pleasure when I receive praise from other people: (pleasure_receive_praise)

Either of the Disagree responses receives a score of 1 and either of the Agree responses receives a score of 0. The SHAPS is scored as the sum of the 14 items so that total scores ranged from 0 to 14. A higher total SHAPS score indicated higher levels of anhedonia. A cutoff score of 2 provides the best discrimination between 'normal' and 'abnormal' level of hedonic tone. (scoring_710601)

protocol.longName: Hedonic Tone or Response to Pleasurable Situations
protocol.preferredDefinition: The Snaith-Hamilton Pleasure Scale (SHAPS) is a self-administered, paper-and-pencil questionnaire with 14 items assessing four domains of pleasure response/hedonic experience: interest/pastimes, social interaction, sensory experience, and food/drink.

form.preferredDefinition: The Computerized Mirror Tracing Persistence Task (MTPT-C) is an automated version of the original Mirror Tracing Persistence Task (Quinn et al., 1996), which requires the construction of a mirror box and multiple copies of polygons to be traced. The MTPT-C simplifies the administration and scoring of this task. In this task, participants are required to trace a red dot along the lines of a geometric shape (e.g., star) using the computer's mouse. However, the mouse moves the red dot in the reverse direction. Each time the participant moves the mouse out of the lines or hesitates for more than 2 seconds, a buzzer sounds, and the dot moves back to the beginning. Three progressively more difficult shapes are used. The first two rounds last 1 minute each, while the third round of the MTPT-C can last up to 7 minutes. Participants may terminate the task at any point during the third round by pressing on the space bar. Distress tolerance is measured by the latency in seconds to task termination. Additionally, the number of errors per second (i.e., number of times the participant has to return to the starting position during the task, divided by the task time) is recorded to control for effects of skill on persistence.

headerInstruction.text: User can download the program for this task at:"http://caperlab.net/taskdownloads/" caperlab.net/taskdownloads

question.questionText: What is the ID number of the session? (mirror_tracing_session_id)
What date did the session take place? (mirror_tracing_session_date)
What time did the session take place? (mirror_tracing_session_time)
What is the subject's ID number? (mirror_tracing_subject_id)
(Before the test) To what extent do you feel excited? (mirror_tracing_pre_excited)
(Before the test) To what extent do you feel mad? (mirror_tracing_pre_mad)
(Before the test) To what extent do you feel interested? (mirror_tracing_pre_interested)
(Before the test) To what extent do you feel frustrated? (mirror_tracing_pre_frustrated)
(Before the test) To what extent do you feel happy? (mirror_tracing_pre_happy)
(Before the test) To what extent do you feel upset? (mirror_tracing_pre_upset)
(Before the test) To what extent do you feel energetic? (mirror_tracing_pre_energetic)
(Before the test) To what extent do you feel embarrassed? (mirror_tracing_pre_embarrassed)
(Before the test) To what extent do you feel proud? (mirror_tracing_pre_proud)
(Before the test) To what extent do you feel nervous? (mirror_tracing_pre_nervous)
In easy mode, what is the total number of errors (off line + too slow) committed by the subject? (mirror_tracing_easy_total_error)
In easy mode, what is the number of times the subject traced outside the line? (mirror_tracing_easy_offline_error)
In easy mode, what is the number of times it took the subject too long to trace the pattern? (mirror_tracing_easy_tooslow_error)
In easy mode, what is the length in seconds it took the subject to complete the task? (mirror_tracing_easy_total_time)
In easy mode, what is the total distance in cm of tracing? (mirror_tracing_easy_total_distance)
In easy mode, what is the median distance in cm of tracing? (mirror_tracing_easy_median_distance)
In easy mode, what is the maximum percentage (out of 100) of tracing around the entire star? (mirror_tracing_easy_maximum_percentage)
In easy mode, what is the average width in cm of the line of the pattern (based on initial titration step)? (mirror_tracing_easy_average_width)
In medium mode, what is the total number of errors (off line + too slow) committed by the subject? (mirror_tracing_medium_total_error)
In medium mode, what is the number of times the subject traced outside the line? (mirror_tracing_medium_offline_error)
In medium mode, what is the number of times it took the subject too long to trace the pattern? (mirror_tracing_medium_tooslow_error)
In medium mode, what is the length in seconds it took the subject to complete the task? (mirror_tracing_medium_total_time)
In medium mode, what is the total distance in cm of tracing? (mirror_tracing_medium_total_distance)
In medium mode, what is the median distance in cm of tracing? (mirror_tracing_medium_median_distance)
In medium mode, what is the maximum percentage (out of 100) of tracing around the entire star? (mirror_tracing_medium_maximum_percentage)
In medium mode, what is the average width in cm of the line of the pattern (based on initial titration step)? (mirror_tracing_medium_average_width)
In hard mode, what is the total number of errors (off line + too slow) committed by the subject? (mirror_tracing_hard_total_error)
In hard mode, what is the number of times the subject traced outside the line? (mirror_tracing_hard_offline_error)
In hard mode, what is the number of times it took the subject too long to trace the pattern? (mirror_tracing_hard_tooslow_error)
In hard mode, what is the length in seconds it took the subject to complete the task? (mirror_tracing_hard_total_time)
In hard mode, what is the total distance in cm of tracing? (mirror_tracing_hard_total_distance)
In hard mode, what is the median distance in cm of tracing? (mirror_tracing_hard_median_distance)
In hard mode, what is the maximum percentage (out of 100) of tracing around the entire star? (mirror_tracing_hard_maximum_percentage)
In hard mode, what is the average width in cm of the line of the pattern (based on initial titration step)? (mirror_tracing_hard_average_width)
(After the test) To what extent do you feel excited? (mirror_tracing_post_excited)
(After the test) To what extent do you feel mad? (mirror_tracing_post_mad)
(After the test) To what extent do you feel interested? (mirror_tracing_post_interested)
(After the test) To what extent do you feel frustrated? (mirror_tracing_post_frustrated)
(After the test) To what extent do you feel happy? (mirror_tracing_post_happy)
(After the test) To what extent do you feel upset? (mirror_tracing_post_upset)
(After the test) To what extent do you feel energetic? (mirror_tracing_post_energetic)
(After the test) To what extent do you feel embarrassed? (mirror_tracing_post_embarrassed)
(After the test) To what extent do you feel proud? (mirror_tracing_post_proud)
(After the test) To what extent do you feel nervous? (mirror_tracing_post_nervous)
In quit mode, what is the total number of errors (off line + too slow) committed by the subject? (mirror_tracing_quit_total_error)
In quit mode, what is the number of times the subject traced outside the line? (mirror_tracing_quit_offline_error)
In quit mode, what is the number of times it took the subject too long to trace the pattern? (mirror_tracing_quit_tooslow_error)
In quit mode, what is the length in seconds it took the subject to complete the task? (mirror_tracing_quit_total_time)
In quit mode, what is the total distance in cm of tracing? (mirror_tracing_quit_total_distance)
In quit mode, what is the median distance in cm of tracing? (mirror_tracing_quit_median_distance)
In quit mode, what is the maximum percentage (out of 100) of tracing around the entire star? (mirror_tracing_quit_maximum_percentage)
In quit mode, what is the average width in cm of the line of the pattern (based on initial titration step)? (mirror_tracing_quit_average_width)

protocol.preferredDefinition: The Computerized Mirror Tracing Persistence Task (MTPT-C) is an automated version of the original Mirror Tracing Persistence Task (Quinn et al., 1996), which requires the construction of a mirror box and multiple copies of polygons to be traced. The MTPT-C simplifies the administration and scoring of this task. In this task, participants are required to trace a red dot along the lines of a geometric shape (e.g., star) using the computer's mouse. However, the mouse moves the red dot in the reverse direction. Each time the participant moves the mouse out of the lines or hesitates for more than 2 seconds, a buzzer sounds, and the dot moves back to the beginning. Three progressively more difficult shapes are used. The first two rounds last 1 minute each, while the third round of the MTPT-C can last up to 7 minutes. Participants may terminate the task at any point during the third round by pressing on the space bar. Distress tolerance is measured by the latency in seconds to task termination. Additionally, the number of errors per second (i.e., number of times the participant has to return to the starting position during the task, divided by the task time) is recorded to control for effects of skill on persistence.

form.preferredDefinition: The Phinney Scale is a 12-item multiethnic identity measure used among adolescents and young adults.

headerInstruction.text: In this country, people come from a lot of different cultures, and there are many different words to describe the different backgrounds or ethnic groups that people come from. Some examples of the names of ethnic groups are Hispanic, Black, As..TRUNCATED

question.questionText: Please answer: In terms of ethnic group, I consider myself to be: (ethnicity_710801)
1. I have spent time trying to find out more about my ethnic group, such asIts history, traditions, and customs. (ethnic_identity_find_out)
2. I am active in organizations or social groups that include mostly members of my own ethnic group. (ethnic_identity_active_ethnic_group)
3. I have a clear sense of my ethnic background and what it means for me. (ethnic_identity_clear_sense)
4. I think a lot about how my life will be affected by my ethnic group membership. (ethnic_identity_affect_life)
5. I am happy that I am a member of the group I belong to. (ethnic_identity_happy_member)
6. I have a strong sense of belonging to my own ethnic group. (ethnic_identity_sense_belonging)
7. I understand pretty well what my ethnic group membership means to me. (ethnic_identity_understand_membership)
8. To learn more about my ethnic background, I have often talked to other people about my ethnic group. (ethnic_identity_learn_talkabout)
9. I have a lot of pride in my ethnic group and its accomplishments. (ethnic_identity_pride_accomplishment)
10. I participate in cultural practices of my own group, such as special food, music, or customs. (ethnic_identity_participate_clultural)
11. I feel a strong attachment towards my own ethnic group. (ethnic_identity_strong_attachment)
12. I feel good about my cultural or ethnic background. (ethnic_identity_feel_good_about)

Procedures and scoring: The affirmation/belonging subscale includes items 3, 5, 6, 7, 9, 11, and 12. The exploration subscaleIncludesItems 1, 2, 4, 8, and 10. (Item 3 loads on both subscales.) Scores range from 14. (scoring_710801)

protocol.preferredDefinition: The Phinney Scale is a 12-item multiethnic identity measure used among adolescents and young adults.

form.longName: PhenX PX710901 - Peer And Family Influence On Smoking
form.preferredDefinition: The Pierce 5-item National Cancer Institute (NCI) measure consists of 5 questions about peer and family smoking. The indices are scored dichotomously as "no exposure" versus "exposure." No exposure to family smoking: "No" on both family items (items 1 and 3). No exposure to friend smoking: "00" on both friend items (items 4 and 5).

module.longName: Peer and Family Influence on Smoking
module.preferredDefinition: Peer and Family Influence on Smoking

question.questionText: Do any of your parents, stepparents, or guardians now smoke cigarettes? (influence_parents_guardians_smoke)
Do you have any older brothers or sisters? (influence_have_older_siblings)
Do your older brothers or sisters smoke cigarettes? (influence_older_siblings_smoke)
Of your best friends who are male, how many of them smoke? Number? (influence_friends_male_smoke)
Of your best friends who are male, how many of them smoke? (male_answer_710901)
Of your best friends who are female, how many of them smoke? Number? (influence_friends_female_smoke)
Of your best friends who are female, how many of them smoke? (female_answer_710901)

protocol.longName: Peer and Family Influence on Smoking
protocol.preferredDefinition: The Pierce 5-item National Cancer Institute (NCI) measure consists of 5 questions about peer and family smoking. The indices are scored dichotomously as "no exposure" versus "exposure." No exposure to family smoking: "No" on both family items (items 1 and 3). No exposure to friend smoking: "00" on both friend items (items 4 and 5).

form.preferredDefinition: The Attention Control Scale (ACS) is a 20-item self-report measure assessing attentional focusing and shifting.

headerInstruction.text: Items are scored on a 4point scale (1 = almost never 2 = sometimes 3 = often 4 = always). R = reversescored item

question.questionText: 1. It's very hard for me to concentrate on a difficult task when there are noises around. (R) (attention_trouble_concentrate_noise)
2. When I need to concentrate and solve a problem, I have trouble focusing my attention. (R) (attention_trouble_solve_problem)
3. When I am working hard on something, I still get distracted by events around me. (R) (attention_working_distracted_events)
4. My concentration is good even if there is music in the room around me. (attention_good_music_around)
5. When concentrating, I can focus my attention so that I become unaware of what's going on in the room around me. (attention_good_unaware_surrounding)
6. When I am reading or studying, I am easily distracted if there are people talking in the same room. (R) (attention_reading_distracted_talking)
7. When trying to focus my attention on something, I have difficulty blocking out distracting thoughts. (R) (attention_difficulty_blocking_thought)
8. I have a hard time concentrating when I'm excited about something. (R) (attention_hard_when_excited)
9. When concentrating I ignore feelings of hunger or thirst. (attention_ignore_hunger)
10. I can quickly switch from one task to another. (attention_quicky_switch_task)
11. It takes me a while to get really involved in a new task. (R) (attention_taskes_awhile_newtask)
12. It is difficult for me to coordinate my attention between the listening and writing required when taking notes during lectures. (R) (attention_difficult_coordinate_during_lecture)
13. I can become interested in a new topic very quickly when I need to. (attention_new_topics)
14. It is easy for me to read or write while I'm also talking on the phone. (attention_easy_read_onphone)
15. I have trouble carrying on two conversations at once. (R) (attention_two_conversations)
16. I have a hard time coming up with new ideas quickly. (R) (attention_new_ideas)
17. After being interrupted or distracted, I can easily shift my attention back to what I was doing before. (attention_distriction_shift_back)
18. When a distracting thought comes to mind, it is easy for me to shift my attention away from it. (attention_distraction_shift_away)
19. It is easy for me to alternate between two different tasks. (attention_easy_alternate_tasks)
20. It is hard for me to break from one way of thinking about something and look at it from another point of view. (R) (attention_another_pov)

Scoring: ACS Full Scale: average of all 20 items.ACS Focusing Subscale: average of items 1, 2, 3, 6, 7, 8, 12ACS Shifting Subscale: average of items 10, 13, 17, 18, 19Higher scores on the ACS Full Scale indicate great attentional control, higher scores on the ACS Focusing Subscale indicate greater attentional focus, and higher scores on the ACS Shifting Subscale indicate greater capacity for attentional shifting. (scoring_711001)

protocol.preferredDefinition: The Attention Control Scale (ACS) is a 20-item self-report measure assessing attentional focusing and shifting.
